description:
Human parainfluenza virus 4a (HPIV-4a) is a member of the Respirovirus genus within the Paramyxoviridae family. It is an enveloped, single-stranded, negative-sense RNA virus that primarily infects the human respiratory tract.

HPIV-4a is one of the four known serotypes of human parainfluenza viruses (HPIV-1, HPIV-2, HPIV-3, and HPIV-4), which are common causes of upper and lower respiratory tract infections, especially in young children.

The virus genome encodes several essential proteins, including the hemagglutinin-neuraminidase (HN) and fusion (F) proteins, which are important for viral attachment, entry, and fusion with host cells. HPIV-4a is typically associated with milder respiratory symptoms compared to other HPIV serotypes, but it can still cause croup, bronchiolitis, and pneumonia, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

Epidemiological studies have shown that HPIV-4a has a global distribution and can cause sporadic infections or outbreaks, often co-circulating with other respiratory viruses. Effective prevention and treatment strategies for HPIV-4a infections are an ongoing area of research and development in the field of respiratory viral diseases.
